The reality is their offer and then your counter offer has narrowed the scope of your negotiation significantly. Letâ€™s give a really wide range where you counter 20%. They offer $50,000, you counter at $60,000 which is a full 20%. Theyâ€™re still only essentially nine increments of a thousand dollars between their offer and your counter offer. You found a narrow set of possible numbers that you're going to wind up at from all of the numbers to somewhere between $50,000 and $60,000. You countered at $60,000, theyâ€™re going to come back with some number. On your script, either youâ€™ll respond with one more number. Letâ€™s say they come back with $55,000 on your $60,000 counter, you say, â€œWell, $55,000 is nice but if you can come up to $58,000 I'm on board.â€ Then, they say okay, you're done. Or, they say, â€œSorry, the best we can do is $56,000.â€ Per my rule of thumb earlier, if they donâ€™t say yes to your last one, now they said $56,000 and you say, â€œWell, I wanted to get up to $58,000 on my last ask. If you can do $56,000 and another week of vacation then I'm on board.â€ That might happen one or two more times. If they say, â€œWe canâ€™t budge on vacation, itâ€™s just not negotiable. Weâ€™re not able to move it in our company. Itâ€™s written in stone.â€ You can say, â€œOkay, I'm going to have to move across the country, can you do $56,000 and a $5,000 relocation.â€ Then, you're pretty much done. It does seem like it can go on forever in your nickel and dime but usually I break it into thousand dollar increments unless I go above $100,000 and then weâ€™re talking about $2,000 increments. It will be one or two volleys on salary and then another one or two volleys on benefits and then itâ€™s over. This will usually happen, itâ€™s often a live conversation on the phone which is why you have the script. It will take literally three minutes, four minutes, until they say either yes or they say okay, I need to go run that by finance which is a soft yes. Dave: Thatâ€™s a good point. But if you're live and negotiating, that kind of counts as one volley even if you go back and forth three or four times. In terms of annoyance and frustration. Iâ€™ve had a client turn me down just because where they started at was so low and I told them upfront youâ€™re probably so low that this may become a frustrating discussion for us. They were like no, letâ€™s keep talking. They really wanted to keep me talking and they really wanted their very low anchor to stay valid. I felt really bad, I thought man, did I really blow it? Did I over negotiate? I kind of looked at their last offer and it was so low that there was just no way I was going to be comfortable working for them at that value. Itâ€™s related to banter we talked about earlier, thereâ€™s some value that if you win the negotiation, the value is so low that you will kick yourself for winning. Youâ€™d be like oh, I canâ€™t believe I took this job at this salary. I was kind of doing that and fortunately their numbers were all below that minimum threshold so I used that to tide myself over.
